transcripts.text: Extraordinary scenes last night.  Can we just talk first of all about the proroguing of Parliament?  Do you think it's a bit bizarre that MPs should claim that it's a shame and hold up signs saying they are silent because Parliament is being prorogued when they're not willing to vote for a general election?

No, it was an unprecedented act of, to be frank, in the words of one Tory MP, tyranny, with an unelected leader shutting down Parliament for five weeks to avoid any scrutiny of his actions.  at a time when we are in a national crisis with the whole future of our country on the line.  Boris Johnson is increasingly becoming the Donald Trump of British politics.

What happened last night was nothing short of outrageous.  I think you've managed to get all the soundbites out, so well done for you on that.  But you say it's an act of tyranny and he's an unelected leader.  I've never voted for the leader of any political party because I've never been a member of a political party.  So I've not voted for your leader.  You've not voted for the leader of the Conservatives.  But if it's an act of tyranny and he's an unelected leader... Wouldn't it be a good idea to get him out as soon as possible or allow him to prove that he is representing the British people as he claims he is?  In which case, I'm going to throw this idea out here, what about having a general election?

A general election is inevitable.  But then what comes first in the national interest is that we have to avoid crashing out of the European Union without a deal.  Boris Johnson is hell-bent on doing precisely that.  The consequences of that, Julia, would be absolutely catastrophic.

Well, they wouldn't, would they?  Even the Bank of England governor, who's been a Ramona to the core, Mark Carney, has admitted that actually with no deal preparations, that's not going to be the case.
Well, with respect, Julia, I know you think you know more about making cars than those who make cars, more about making planes than those who make planes.
No, I don't.  I don't pretend that at all.  But I do listen to the experts.  I tell you what, I don't know as much, you don't know as much as the man who's, for instance, running Doverport.
Are you interviewing yourself?
No, I'm just, you're telling me what I think and I'm telling you I don't think that.

When you've stopped, I'll give you an answer.  is that the unmistakable and overwhelming voice of the world of work, of industry and employment and the trade unions, is that a no-deal Brexit would be catastrophic.  We're already seeing mounting problems.  For example, production in the car industry fell by 10% last month.  We have to get a deal.  And what we cannot allow Boris Johnson to do is to cut and run because that would be to betray the national interest.  The national interest determines that our focus must be getting a deal on Brexit.  And then, of course, we will have a general election.

OK, let's also remember that the same people who are warning of catastrophe now are the same people who warned about catastrophe if we voted for Brexit at all.  Any version of Brexit, they say that.  However, that is what the British people voted for.  You could argue it's in the national interest that we do actually implement democratic votes.  Yes.  You said that there will be a general election.  So when are we saying there'll be a general election?  Because it looks like if we don't get Parliament back till the 14th of October, and no reason to think that would happen before, we've got the European Council meeting, 19th of October, the Prime Minister is supposed to go to Brussels and say, I want to have an extension unless he's got a deal.  No expectation he'll get a deal at this point, given the situation we're in.  In which case, the earliest point we can have an election is the 28th of November.  Will the Labour Party be voting for a general election at that earliest opportunity?

All parties, opposition parties, have been working together to put the national interest first.  What comes first is to stop a no-deal Brexit.  There then will be, inevitably, a general election.  We're not going to announce this morning the precise date of that.  Instead, what we're focused on are, to be frank, Julia, are the people who get us out of bed in the morning, like in my case, in one of the poorest constituencies in Britain, the Jaguar plant, which has transformed the lives of thousands of workers.  And I know what is vital in terms of their interest because they tell me that the last thing they want is a no deal.  And as one of the leading trade union representatives said to me yesterday... Jack, tell them in the House of Commons to stop sodding about and getting us a deal because otherwise it's put us at risk.

And you don't think it'd be a good idea to test what the British people do want by having a general election before October 30th?  And I completely accept the concerns about Boris Johnson shifting the day.  If they're away getting around that, you wouldn't be able to use the Fixed-Term Parliament Act motion in that case.  But if they're away, look, I'm a leaver.  I would not accept him shifting the day.  I think that would be outrageous.  If we could actually get a date that was before that time, we could test whether or not the British people do or do not want a no-deal Brexit.  Why would you not allow that to happen?
There will be a general election.  But you're not listening to what I'm saying.  No, I'm not.
You know I have ears.  I can hear what you're saying.

No, well, in the national interest, we have to put beyond any doubt that there will not be a no-deal Brexit.  It would be utterly responsible and to betray our responsibilities if we were to do anything else.  And all you're all you're focused on, Judy, with the greatest of respect, because you're an ardent Brexiteer and I know you are.  All you are focused on is, to be frank, the playing of political games.  Well, this is too serious to play politics with.
You don't think we have.  you don't think we've been seeing any political games being played by Remainers?
we're going to rule out a no-deal Brexit in the national interest, and then there will be a general election.
Why do you get to decide what the national interest is rather than the British people?
The national interest for me is determined by the people that I represent.  And out there in the country, the voice of the world of work, which is absolutely key...
The voice of the world of work?

The voice of the world of work, yes, yes.  All of the employers' organisations, all of the major industrial organisations... and the trade unions all say with the same voice, we cannot have a no-deal Brexit.
So if you're so sure that the country is with you, go for a general election and prove that and then make darn sure we don't get a no-deal Brexit by being in government.

There will be a general election.  But forgive me if I say this, is that the idea that what we do is to shut down Parliament, then have a general election, and the clock is ticking towards the 31st of October.  with the danger that potentially we plunge over into an abyss, to be frank, which make our country poorer for years to come.  No, Julia, no.

My Ramona bingo card is being ticked off very, very well this morning, I have to say.  But the issue is, though, is that you, like many other on the Labour benches and the Liberal Democrats, it's not that you don't want a no-deal Brexit.  You don't want Brexit at all to happen.  That's the reality.  You were elected, though, on a manifesto that said you would implement the Brexit bill.  Now, I've looked at that referendum voting slip again and again and again and I've yet to see the words with a deal on it.  It says leave and it says remain.

Ah, well, thank you for saying that because you tell me any one of the major figures in the leave campaign who ever stalked the country and said leave and leave without a deal, they did not do it.  On the contrary, from Boris Johnson downwards... it was said that a good deal would be secured for Britain.
Absolutely.
I agree with you.  The people of Britain, yes, voted to leave.  And my very strong view is that we have to do everything possible to meet their democratic needs.

Jeremy, on that, I agree with you.  However, of course, we know that on the Remain side, they made it very clear that we would, in their words, crash out without a deal if we didn't get a good deal.  The reality is, of course, very difficult to get a deal when you've got half of the British Parliament working on the side of the EU.  Can I ask you also about the Speaker of the House?
What's the other side of the EU?
Yes, yes.  Shame on you.  Shame on you.  Jack Jomie, with all due respect, shame on you and your colleagues.  Now, yesterday...
Shame on you, Julia.
Yes, carry on.
What you are doing is impugning the integrity of MPs...

Oh, absolutely.  100% I'm impugning the integrity of MPs.  I'm impugning the integrity of some former cabinet ministers working in the British government who were actually on the side of the EU.  Downright I am.  And so were many voters listening to this right now.
So this... This morning's story, therefore, is Julia Hartley Brewer.
No, it's not a story at all.
The un-elected arch-Brexiteer is lampooning members of Parliament on the basis of voting with their conscience and in the best interest of their constituents.
You might be voting with your conscience.  You're not voting with the manifesto on which you were elected, Jack Dromey.
The manifesto was to honour the wish of the British people.
To deliver Brexit.
I work night and day to honour that, to honour that.  but that we have to protect the interests of our country as we leave the European Union.  Okay.

I do want to ask you about the speaker, Jack Dromey, if I can.  You described the speaker yesterday as one of the finest speakers ever, the finest since 1945, and a decent guy.  Can I clarify?  Is this the same John Bercow who was criticised in a parliamentary report on institutional bullying by Dame Laura Cox?  And is it the same one who the former Black Rod David Leakey said was unfit for public office and of whom lots of people in his office were terrified?  Are you sure that John Bercow is a decent guy and one of the finest speakers ever?

In his role as Speaker, he has been an outstanding champion of Parliament, holding the executive to account.  The whole history of Speakers, some of whom have lost their heads over the centuries, is that the role of the Speaker is to stand up for Parliament, never to allow government to trample over our democracy.  John has done that.  He's discharged his responsibilities admirably.
Do you think the role of the Speaker is also to stand up for people who claim they've been bullied or sexually harassed in the House of Commons?
You're asking me about his role as Speaker?
That is one of his roles as Speaker, yes.
I think that there are real problems.  about the way the Commons conducts itself in terms of investigations into allegations of inappropriate behaviour.  I think there's real problems.

And the fact that Dame Laura Cox carried out a report and said he was part of the problem, his office was part of the problem, and that it couldn't be sorted out unless or until his office was changed, i.e.  the Speaker left.  And you're quite happy for him to stay in that role?
I know you've had your readout from Conservative Central.

I don't get a readout from Conservative Central.  Jack Dromey, I have no party political affiliation.  I think I've probably voted for your political party more often than I've voted for any other, actually.  I don't know why you think you know my politics.
Of late, you wear your prejudices on your sleeve.
I'm not prejudiced.  I have my own opinions, like voters in this country are allowed to do.
You're asking me about the man as a Speaker... holding government to account.  He has done that admirably.

So it's okay, as long as he holds the government to account, then that's fine.  It doesn't matter that he allows bullying and harassment of staff, including accusations.  He is denied, in fairness, but numerous allegations of bullying and harassment from his own staff.  You're quite happy to praise a man as a decent guy, one of the finest speakers ever, who has those accusations against him.
No, I'm not.  You just did.  I repeat, I repeat, I think there are real problems about the way that the Commons conducts...
So you don't think he's a decent guy?
There are real problems about the way...
So you don't think he's a decent guy?
I will say it for one final time.  In the history of speakers...
Is he or is he not a decent guy?
He is, in the history of speakers... He is a man who has discharged his responsibilities to this country and to our parliamentary democracy.
Is he or is he not a decent guy?
And you can try all you want.
Is he or is he not a decent guy?
He is a decent man.
You think he's a decent man?
You can try all you want.  You can try all you want.  to take a different view, the view of Boris Johnson.
It's not the view of Boris Johnson.  It's the view of an awful lot of MPs in the House of Commons on many different sides.  He's been very useful to you, so you're willing to let it go.
There was a time when you were more balanced in your outlook.
When I agreed with you.
Now, as an ardent Brexiteer...
That's not an insult, by the way.  Do you do know that being an ardent Brexiteer isn't actually an insult?

You would push to one side centuries of parliamentary tradition.  I will not do that.  I am proud to have been elected as a Member of Parliament to stand up for my constituents.  I respect their decision to vote to leave.  I have worked night and day to secure with others a deal that will protect the British national interest.  And forgive me if I say it, but one final time, That is where my focus is.  I will never let down the people I represent.

OK, apart from you won't give them a general election.  Labour MP Jack Dromey, Shadow Pensions Minister.  Thank you very much for that.  8.20 is the time.  You're listening to The Breakfast Show on Talk Radio with Julia Hartley-Brewer, powered by The Times.  Be well informed.  Pick up the...
